t: Proverbs 31
The Words of Lemuel
The*pn words of King Lemuel, a*ln pronouncement that his mother taught him:
What*pn should I say, my son? What,*ln son of my womb? What,*ln son of my vows?
Don’t*ln spend your energy on women or*ln your efforts on those who destroy kings.
It*ln is not for kings, Lemuel, it*ln is not for kings to drink wine or*ln for rulers to desire beer.
Otherwise,*ln he will drink, forget*ln what is decreed, and*ln pervert justice for all the oppressed.
Give*ln beer to one who is dying and*ln wine to one whose life is bitter.
Let*ln him drink so that he can forget his poverty and*ln remember his trouble no more.
Speak*ln up for those who have no voice, for*ln the justice of all who are dispossessed.
Speak*ln up, judge righteously, and*ln defend the cause of the oppressed and needy.
In Praise of a Wife of Noble Character
Who*pn can find a wife of noble character? She*ln is far more precious than jewels.
The*ln heart of her husband trusts in her, and*ln he will not lack anything good.
She*ln rewards him with good, not evil, all*ln the days of her life.
She*ln selects wool and flax and*ln works with willing hands.
She*ln is like the merchant ships, bringing*ln her food from far away.
She*ln rises while it is still night and*ln provides food for her household and*ln portions for her female servants.
She*ln evaluates a field and buys it; she*ln plants a vineyard with her earnings.
She*ln draws on her strength and*ln reveals that her arms are strong.
She*ln sees that her profits are good, and*ln her lamp never goes out at night.
She*ln extends her hands to the spinning staff, and*ln her hands hold the spindle.
Her*ln hands reach out to the poor, and*ln she extends her hands to the needy.
She*ln is not afraid for her household when it snows, for*ln all in her household are doubly clothed.
She*ln makes her own bed coverings; her*ln clothing is fine linen and purple.
Her*ln husband is known at the city gates, where*ln he sits among the elders of the land.
She*ln makes and sells linen garments; she*ln delivers belts to the merchants.
Strength*ln and honor are her clothing, and*ln she can laugh at the time to come.
Her*ln mouth speaks wisdom, and*ln loving instruction is on her tongue.
She*ln watches over the activities of her household and*ln is never idle.
Her*ln children rise up and call her blessed; her*ln husband also praises her:
“Many*ln women have done noble deeds, but*ln you surpass them all!”
Charm*ln is deceptive and beauty is fleeting, but*ln a woman who fears the Lord*s will be praised.
Give*ln her the reward of her labor, and*ln let her works praise her at the city gates.
